content.content: image996×634 68.4 KB   Introduction At the Decentralized Voter Committee last night (video below), I introduced the concept of the “Endgame Party” which is an attempt at further formalizing the role of Decentralized Voter Committees as tools for bringing aligned voters together and identify delegates that vote according to their interests. The Endgame Plan itself will have multiple stages of voting, including a preliminary Signal Request and the Endgame Plan Launch MIP - But those votes will not be possible to hold until the complete details of the Endgame Plan (which still include another 3 parts in addition to part 4 which will be presented at the DVC today and posted tomorrow), and some simplified material has been broadly released. Before we get to that point, there are multiple short term improvements MKR holders can help prioritize and focus on that are important regardless of the outcome of the Endgame Plan. This include the Focus Objectives that I have been presenting at the Decentralized Voter Committes. Particularly getting Decentralized Voter Committees up and running so that MKR voters become more active in expressing their opinions and interests is fundamental to get Maker Governance more healthy. Additionally it will be very helpful and stabilizing to be able to get a general sense of the level of overall support of the direction of the Endgame Plan, even if all the details have not been published to be iterated and agreed on yet. The Endgame Party helps serve that purpose, and the basic idea is simple. The DVC calls that I have been hosting so far will be renamed to Endgame Party DVCs. We will accumulate a large amount of MKR that delegates to specific Endgame Delegates that attend these calls, and vote according to the general direction that reaches consensus on the calls. These delegates will also help arrange the DVCs, and increasingly become responsible for the content as I start to be able to step back and let the Endgame Party take on a life of its own.  Direction of the Endgame Party The general direction of the Endgame Party is improvement and eventual implementation of the Endgame Plan. If it is rejected (or invalidated through failure of the first MetaDAO), The Endgame Party will instead pursue the implementation of a Rai+ model where Maker is significantly simplified and stripped down to its simple, powerful and highly efficient core as a USD pegged stablecoin that is collateralized by blue chip decentralized asset and d3m exposure, stablecoins and safe haven bonds. The Endgame Party is unique in that it is designed from the start, like the Endgame Plan, to be self-decentralizing by eventually splitting up into two separate parties: The Hawk Party and the Dove Party that have general opposing views on things like rates, budgets, growth vs profit etc, top down vs bottom up, etc. This split will ideally happen at the time of the Endgame Plan Launch, so users that delegate due to voting incentives will be presented with a simple but meaningful choice of how they want their votes to impact the protocol. It also means that even if no other major DVC Parties emerge, the Endgame Party will automatically ensure that there are checks and balances in Maker Governance as it starts ossifying and reach an immutable endgame state. If you want more context of the Endgame Party and Decentralized Voter Committees in general you can watch the recording from last night: Open Decentralized Voter Committee | June 15, 2022 - YouTube (warning: veeeeery long) Here’s also a lot of debate for additional context: Decentralized voter committees: Wednesday and Thursday 9pm CEST - getting real edition  Endgame Delegate signup This post is also meant to be a place where delegates can “sign up” to help run the Endgame Party by committing to it in replies to this thread. This is open to everyone, but you will be expected to attend as many Endgame Party Decentralized Voter Committees as possible, and vote in general accordance with their direction, as well as contribute with information, ideas and proposals. Exactly how membership of the Endgame Party is determined will be figured out as we start to see recurring attendance of the Decentralized Voter Committee calls, but my simple starting point for DVC parties is that the largest MKR holder determines membership, and all members have full veto rights but can be removed if they are not seeking consensus and compromise. The party can even split up in two if there is a broader schism. Rearrangements like this should be common and expected, and be smooth because of the decentralized and permissionless nature of DVCs and DVC parties. Eventually a requirement of any kind of DVC Party is that members prove their MKR holdings (exactly how will be determined in the future) so that it is possible to reason about the actual voting power of a particular DVC party. This will influence how the majority of my own delegation is distributed (although I will not exclusively delegate to Endgame delegates), and will provide a clear place for other voters to delegate if they support the Endgame Plan and want to see it come to life, even if they dont want to join the DVCs or otherwise get in the weeds. I’m also expecting to be able to get some of the other large MKR holders to delegate to Endgame Delegates. To sign up as an Endgame Delegate, simply reply to this post and write a simple message with your intention to help be a part of the Endgame Party, and include details such as your view and input on the Endgame plan or how you can contribute to the Endgame Party DVC calls.

content.content: ChrisBlec:  but i’m wondering now what you see as the future for the delegates who don’t sign on to this plan. do you feel that they’ll become obsolete under the 1-party Endgame system? or do you somehow envision competing parties? it would also be good to know if you have achieved consensus with other MKR whales on the Endgame Plan. is there an appetite from other whales for a 2nd party? or do you have reason to believe that Endgame will ultimately be the only horse in this race?   Like I wrote in the post, I still plan to delegate to certain delegates that are not aligned with the Endgame Party, because I think they bring value to the protocol regardless. But beyond that, it simply doesn’t make any sense for me to delegate to someone that I don’t agree with, and on the contrary I think there is a lot to gain from creating a real incentive for delegates to seek out voters to activate, as obviously it would be very beneficial to have more active voters, and as many governance parties as possible. Main caveat is that governance parties has to represent legitimate opinions of real MKR holders that are looking out for Maker and the value of MKR itself, not special interests that try to e.g. onboard their own collateral, which would of course be harmful. When I first started preparing for the Endgame Plan proposal I was mostly convinced that some kind of clear counter proposal would emerge that would promise to solve the same core issues but with a different approach and implementation. So far this has not happened, which is unfortunate, because while I really believe in the incredible power and potential of the Endgame Plan it would have benefitted greatly from actual critical and intellectual challenge and weighed properly as a tradeoff, and ultimately if some other proposal won through a proper decentralized governance process that would still be mission accomplished for me and would allow me to “retire”. At this point I think it is less likely there will be real voter organization that will try to push for an alternative to the Endgame Plan, since it has been telegraphed so far in advance to all the people I think would be most able to do something like that. but I have also not pre-lobbied whales or anything like that, and in general I dont spend much time tracking or interacting with other large MKR holders. So ultimately I don’t know, it is even possible that some secret group of voters is planning some big reveal any day now. However, I do plan to now (after having presented most of it) begin the process try to get as many as possible on board with the Endgame Plan to maximize alignment in the ecosystem to make the transition as successful as possible.

content.content: 2 options are being presented by someone who has close to unstoppable power in (and passion for) this DAO: A) Accept this offer, join the “Endgame Party”, promise my votes to it and (most importantly) be incentivized to limit my dissent. B) Reject this offer, turning down the incentive, but still monitor & participate in the development of the “Endgame Party”, supporting it where it matches up with my platform & principles and opposing it where it does not. I do not want to put myself in a position where I may be incentivized to compromise on my principles. Option A requires a promise that I simply cannot make. I have to choose Option B. The Endgame Plan has some noble & desirable goals. But reaching those goals will require the DAO to travel down a perilous & somewhat experimental road. If there are only yes-people involved in these decisions, the Plan could easily fail and even bring the DAO down with it. Critical and adversarial thought will be required for any of these plans to safely develop, and it will be vital that we have delegates who are not incentivized to ignore fatal flaws and who won’t hesitate to suggest hitting the “pause” or “abort” buttons if it becomes evident that these plans have gone off the rails. I respectfully refuse the offered incentive to vote with the crowd. I will enthusiastically & constructively participate in discussions about the future of this DAO and I’ll support initiatives that match up with my principles. But I will also dissent without hesitation if things start moving in a dangerous direction. I’m here because I believe that MakerDAO has the opportunity to become vital to the future of global finance and unstoppable in nature. I want to see it succeed and thrive for decades to come. Maybe the Endgame Plan will get us there! But maybe, at some point, it will become clear that it will not do what we need it to do. Or worse, it may become clear that the Endgame Plan will hurt the DAO. None of us can know for sure how this will turn out. We need to be ready to acknowledge any eventuality. I will do everything that I can as a delegate to contribute towards the goal of an unstoppable MakerDAO while staying true to the principles that brought me here and, most importantly, avoiding any incentive to “look the other way” on critical flaws.

content.content: Look guys, you have three options available to you, the three C’s: You can collaborate, you can compete or you can complain. Only the first two of those options are meaningful in any way. Less insults, and more concrete alternative proposals or specific input please. Toxicity isn’t going to get you the results you want.  you’re never talking about user experience  This is the kind of coherent input I appreciate, even if its hidden in a drama sandwich and presented in the passive aggressive form  . I completely agree that a decentralized end user experience, and focus on end users ability to interact with properly decentralized DeFi services, needs to be a top priority, and they must never be downgraded from first class citizens alongside infrastructure, backend and institutional users. But you are wrong in your criticism because this is literally the core focus of the MetaDAOs, which the cornerstones of the entire endgame plan. They are built around a realistic way to provide user friendly, but fully decentralized, uncensorable and secure frontends both for vaults, dai/DSR and most importantly maker governance and voting. Additionally MetaDAOs are fundamentally about branding, community building, growth, metaverse presence and belonging. And last but not least none of these things matter if they can’t be accomplished sustainably, meaning they need to be profitable, and they need to not infect maker governance with endlessly growing complexity. MetaDAOs deliver all of these things… and that’s just getting started on their massive benefits. I wish the complainers here could learn from Chris and Maker Man and realize that the only thing you are in a position to demand from me is transparency, and that as long as you have that, the Maker Governance process provides you all the tools you need to have your fair share of influence.
